The pair (S, R), where S is a subring of R, is called a ring extension.

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

Does the concept of a/an Ring Extension need to be defined for a definition of a/an Factorial ring/unique factorization domain to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Factorial ring or unique factorization domain (UFD) focuses on the properties of elements within a single ring, specifically their factorization into irreducibles or primes. The definition of a UFD involves conditions that apply internally to the ring itself, such as every non-zero non-unit element being expressible uniquely as a product of irreducible elements, and these irreducibles being prime.

On the other hand, the concept of a Ring Extension involves the relationship between two rings, where one ring is a subring of another. This concept is used to study properties that might change or be inherited when moving from a smaller ring (subring) to a larger ring.

Given these definitions, the concept of a Ring Extension is not necessary to define or understand a Factorial ring/UFD. The definition and properties of a UFD can be fully understood and applied without reference to another ring or a subring relationship, as it pertains solely to the internal structure and properties of the ring itself.
